Table 2 Samples BET surface areas (m2/g) The content of surface Ce3+ (%) The content of surface oxygen vacancy (%) P-CeO2 NPs-4 nm 124.6 24.4 6.1 P-CeO2 NPs-10 nm 98.3 37.8 9.5 R-CeO2 NPs 87.1 31.1 7.8 S-CeO2 NPs 107.1 32.4 8.1 Sodium laurate-assisted CeO2 nanoparticles as highly efficient and recyclable catalysts for cyanosilylation reaction Hao Wu Investigation Data curation Writing – original draft a b Linkai Han a Ni Wang Validation Formal analysis a Ling-Xia Yun Validation Formal analysis a Zhonghua Xiang Writing – review & editing a Jie-Xin Wang Supervision Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition a b ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Organic-Inorganic Composites, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing 100029, PR China State Key Laboratory of Organic-Inorganic Composites, Beijing University of Chemical Technology Beijing 100029 PR China State Key Laboratory of Organic-Inorganic Composites, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing 100029, PR China b Research Center of the Ministry of Education for High Gravity Engineering and Technology, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing, 100029, PR China Research Center of the Ministry of Education for High Gravity Engineering and Technology, Beijing University of Chemical Technology Beijing 100029 PR China Research Center of the Ministry of Education for High Gravity Engineering and Technology, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing, 100029, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author at: State Key Laboratory of Organic-Inorganic Composites, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing 100029, PR China. State Key Laboratory of Organic-Inorganic Composites, Beijing University of Chemical Technology Beijing 100029 PR China Cyanosilylation of aromatic aldehydes has always been a promising reaction in the organic synthesis. Herein, we use sodium laurate (SL) as capping agent to synthesize CeO2 nanoparticles (NPs) with different morphologies and sizes, which are adopted as catalysts for the cyanosilylation reaction at room temperature. The obtained polyhedron-shaped CeO2 NPs with an average size of 10 nm are proved to have rich oxygen defects and abundant Lewis/Brönsted acidic sites, exhibiting excellent catalytic properties. The reaction can be rapidly completed in 1 h in heptane and 0.75 h under solvent-free conditions, achieving a high yield of over 99%. More importantly, the as-prepared catalysts possess outstanding recyclability that the reaction still keeps a high yield of over 98% in the 5th cycle. Density functional theory calculation is further employed to demonstrate SL grafted on CeO2 can greatly suppress the adsorption of hydrogen cyanide on the catalyst, thereby accelerating the reaction process. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords CeO2 nanoparticles Sodium laurate Cyanosilylation reaction Efficient catalysts Recyclability DFT calculation 1 Introduction The formation of C-C bond is a vital reaction in the organic synthesis [1,2], which employs structurally simple and readily available reagents to produce value-added chemicals [3,4]. Among the various C-C bond formation reactions, cyanosilylation of carbonyl compounds as a common and significant reaction has been extensively used in the agricultural and pharmaceutical industry to synthesize α-hydroxycarbonyl compounds, non-steroid anti-inflammatory drugs and β-amino alcohols [5–8]. Especially in recent years, with the development of green chemistry and the shortage of medical resources, cyanosilylation reaction has attracted growing attentions due to its mild reaction conditions, fine target product selectivity as well as a broad scope of applications [9,10]. However, the rate of cyanosilylation reaction is quite slow at room temperature, which limits the practical applications of such kind of reaction [11–13]. A numerous of homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts have been reported for the cyanosilylation reaction such as alkaloid, small organic molecules, metal-organic frameworks and metal oxides [3,14–17]. Among them, metal oxides such as Fe3O4, ZnO and CeO2 are regarded as potential catalysts in the cyanosilylation reaction because of their easy availability, low cost and unique performance [18–20]. Especially, when the size of metal oxides is reduced to the nanoscale, the catalysts exhibit the advantages of exposing more accessible active sites to reactant molecules, larger surface area as well as richer oxygen vacancies in the solid structure [21]. The Lewis and Brönsted acidity of metal oxide nanoparticles usually dominates the efficiency of the cyanosilylation reaction process [22]. But the release of hydrogen cyanide (HCN) during the reaction can inactivate the Brönsted/Lewis acidic sites and cause the decrease of reaction rate and the difficulty of catalyst recycling [19]. Therefore, it is very important to design and develop highly efficient and recyclable metal oxide nanoparticles for promoting the cyanosilylation reaction. CeO2 has been widely employed as a bifunctional acid-base catalyst because of its outstanding oxygen storage capacity, unique Ce4+/Ce3+ redox cycle, and high catalytic activity, which has a great potential in the organic synthesis [23–25]. CeO2 surface with exposed active sites and rich defects plays an important role in the adsorption of specific reactants, charge transfer as well as the process of chemical reactions [26]. Thus, there are numerous reports focused on improving the surface properties of CeO2 by metal deposition, surfactant modification as well as heterojunctions fabrication [27,28]. Among them, the surfactant modification is a cheap and effective approach to orient the growth of nanocrystals for different morphologies with specific facets, and prevent particles agglomeration to expose more active sites on catalysts. Herein, CeO2 nanoparticles (NPs) with different morphologies and sizes were successfully synthesized with sodium laurate (SL) as surfactant by adjusting pH value, temperature and the type of solvent during the preparation process. After that, the obtained CeO2 NPs were applied in the cyanosilylation reaction, exhibiting high catalytic activities. The effects of CeO2 morphology and size, catalysts amount, solvents, as well as reaction temperature on the yield were explored. The recyclability of the catalysts was also tested. Furthermore, the mechanism of the cyanosilylation reaction catalyzed by SL modified CeO2 NPs was investigated by combining experiments and density functional theory (DFT) calculations. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals Cerium nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3⋅6H2O), cerium chloride heptahydrate (CeCl3⋅7H2O), sodium laurate (SL), N,N-Dimethylformamide (DMF) and dichloromethane (DCM) were got from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co. Other reagents were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co. All the chemicals were used without further purification. Deionized water was produced by a water purification system (RO-DI plus, Hitech, PRC). 2.2 Synthesis of CeO2 NPs with different morphologies and sizes 2.2.1 Polyhedron-shaped CeO2 NPs-10 nm Initially, 5.4 g Ce(NO3)3.6H2O was dissolved in 45 mL deionized water as cerium precursor, and 0.6 g SL was dissolved in 5 mL deionized water at 40 °C under vigorous stirring. Afterwards, the cerium precursor solution was added into a flask containing 15 mL NH3·H2O aqueous solution (3.12 M) at 70 °C under stirring. After that, H2O2 (0.3 wt%) was added drop by drop in the flask to oxidize the products. In this process, the purple precipitate (Ce (III)) gradually turned yellow (Ce (IV)). Subsequently, the SL solution was poured into the flask, and the reaction lasted for 1 h at 70 °C under stirring. Finally, the obtained polyhedron-shaped CeO2 NPs-10 nm (P-CeO2 NPs-10 nm) were washed with ethanol for two times and further centrifuged at 6000 rpm. The as-prepared CeO2 NPs can be dispersed in nonpolar solvents such as heptane, benzene and dichloromethane to form nanodispersions. 2.2.2 Polyhedron-shaped CeO2 NPs-4 nm According to the above experimental conditions, polyhedron-shaped CeO2 NPs-4 nm (P-CeO2 NPs-4 nm) could be prepared by replacing deionized water with methanol, and decreasing the reaction temperature to 65 °C. 2.2.3 Rod-shaped CeO2 NPs According to the above experimental conditions, rod-shaped CeO2 NPs (R-CeO2 NPs) could be synthesized by increasing the reaction temperature to 85 °C and adjusting the pH value of solvent to 9 by NH3·H2O. 2.2.4 Spindle-shaped CeO2 NPs According to the above experimental conditions, spindle-shaped CeO2 NPs (S-CeO2 NPs) could be synthesized by using methanol as solvent and replacing Ce(NO3)3·6H2O with CeCl3·7H2O at 65 °C. 2.3 Cyanosilylation reaction A typical cyanosilylation reaction process was carried out as below: benzaldehyde (1.0 mmol), trimethylsilyl cyanide (TMSCN, 2.0 mmol), and CeO2 NPs (0.02 mmol, 2 mol%) were placed in a capped glass vial and stirred at room temperature for 1 h under solvent or solvent-free conditions. Afterwards, the catalysts were washed with ethanal once and separated by centrifugation at 8000 rpm. And then the catalysts were dried in the oven at 60 °C for 30 min to regenerate the activity for the following recycling experiments. The equation of cyanosilylation reaction is as follows: Image 1 . 2.4 Computational models and methods All the DFT calculations in this work were done by the Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP). The projector augmented wave (PAW) potentials and Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange-correlation functional were adopted. All calculations were conducted using a plane-wave kinetic energy cutoff of 400 eV. The energy convergence cri-terion was set to be 10−4 eV, and the force on each ion was converged to less than 0.03 eV/Å. The Brillouin zone of bulk CeO2 was sampled with (6 ×6 ×6) Monkhorst-Pack k-point mesh. A two-layer structure was constructed, and the bottom layer was fixed. (111) surface was selected as the reaction crystal plane and a vacuum layer of 25 Å along the z-direction was used to avoid interaction of neighbouring images. A (4 × 4 × 1) supercell was constructed and (2 ×2 ×1) Monkhorst-Pack k-point mesh was used for Brillouin zone sampling. 10% of the oxygen atoms on the surface of CeO2 were removed to simulate the oxygen vacancies on the surface. Adsorption energy ΔE of A group adsorbed on the surface was defined as: ΔE = E*A – (E* + EA) where *A and * denote the adsorption of A group on substrates and the bare substrates, EA denotes the energy of A group. Here, A group includes reactants and modifier. 2.5 Characterization The size, lattice structure and morphology of CeO2 catalysts were examined with a high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM, JEOL-950, Japan). Nano Measurer software was employed to calculate the average particle size of CeO2 NPs by measuring over 50 particles in the TEM images. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were tested by a Bruker equipment. Fourier transformed infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) was tested by a Perkin Elmer Frontier. Thermogravimetric analysis (TG) was characterized on a Netzsch TG209F3. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) was tested via a BSDPS(M). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed with a Thermo ESCALAB 250Xi. The reactants and products in the cyanosilylation reaction process were detected by Gas Chromatography-Mass Spectrometry (GCMS, Thermo Fisher ISQ Trace1300). Pyridine-adsorption IR analysis was performed on a Tensor 27 and the detailed experimental conditions were carried out according to the literature [29]. The number of Lewis (L) and Brönsted (B) acidic sites was calculated by the following formula: C (pyridine on Lewis sites) = 1.42 × IA (L) × R2/W C (pyridine on Brönsted sites) = 1.88 × IA (B) × R2/W where C is the concentration [mmol/g catalyst], IA is the integrated absorbance of the L or B band (cm−1), R is the radius of the catalyst disk (cm), and W is the mass of the disk (mg). 3 Results and discussion Fig. 1 shows the representative HRTEM images and XRD patterns of the obtained CeO2 with different morphologies and sizes. P-CeO2 NPs-4 nm mainly expose the most stable (111) planes as well as a small proportion of (200) planes, and can be seen as polyhedron-shape nanoparticles dominated by truncated octahedron (Fig. 1a). Correspondingly, P-CeO2 NPs-10 nm expose diverse planes such as (111), (220) and (200) (Fig. 1b), demonstrating that the as-prepared CeO2 NPs-10 nm have polyhedral structures defined by enclosed octahedral (Fig. S1). Furthermore, R-CeO2 NPs with length (100–150 nm) and diameter (5–10 nm) expose (220) and (200) faces were formed under the strong alkaline condition (pH=9) and high temperature (85 °C) (Fig. 1c), while the release of Cl- from CeCl3⋅7H2O precursor tended to orient the growth of CeO2 nanocrystals into secondary structures, thereby forming S-CeO2 NPs with length (50–100 nm) and diameter (20–40 nm) (Fig. 1d). The long hydrocarbon chain of SL endows the modified CeO2 NPs the ability to disperse into nonpolar solvents such as heptane, benzene and dichloromethane (Fig. S2). Meanwhile, SL can prevent the nanoparticles from agglomeration to achieve more active sites on the surface of CeO2 (Fig. S3a and Fig. S3b). It is worth noting that R-CeO2 NPs and S-CeO2 NPs can not be formed well without the addition of SL, indicating SL as capping agent plays an important role in the oriented growth of CeO2 nanoparticles (Fig. S3c and Fig. S3d). Fig. 1e further demonstrates that the main diffractions peaks of the obtained products are in accordance with planes of cubic fluorite structure [30]. P-CeO2 NPs-10 nm and R-CeO2 NPs have stronger and narrower diffraction peaks than other CeO2 NPs, which may be due to their relatively larger particle sizes and better crystallization from the synthesis at a relatively higher temperature. Fig. 2 shows the FTIR spectra and TG curves of the obtained CeO2 NPs. The stretching frequency peaks of carboxylate group (-COO-) at 1434 and 1535 cm−1 confirm that the carboxy group (-COOH) of SL dehydrates with the hydrogenated O atom on the surface of CeO2 to form a stable modified structure [31] (Fig. 2a). As shown in Fig. 2b, the modified CeO2 samples have two stages of weight loss. The weight loss before 200 °C is mainly attributed to adsorbed water, and the grafted SL does not start decomposing until the temperature exceeds 300 °C. The SL grafting ratio of P-CeO2 NPs-10 nm is slightly lower (~15%) compared with that of P-CeO2 NPs-4 nm (~22%), demonstrating that the smaller nanoparticles can graft more SL. Meanwhile, the obtained CeO2 NPs with different morphologies have the outstanding thermal stability and dispersibility, which has a great potential in many fields, such as organic synthesis, lubricating oil and oil-soluble UV cosmetics [32,33]. Fig. 3 illustrates the effects of CeO2 shape, SL modification of catalysts, the addition amount of catalysts, and reaction temperature on the cyanosilylation reaction. As shown in Fig. 3a, P-CeO2 NPs-10 nm exhibit the highest catalytic efficiency in converting benzaldehyde to α-[(trimethylsilyl)oxy]benzeneacetonitrile among the six samples, which can achieve a high yield of over 99% in 1 h (Fig. S4). In comparison, P-CeO2 NPs-4 nm, R-CeO2 NPs and S-CeO2 NPs can complete the reaction in 3 h, 3 h and 4 h, respectively, while the cyanosilylation reaction without catalysts can only achieve a yield of 33.1% in 4 h. Furthermore, unmodified polyhedron-shaped CeO2 NPs-4 nm (UM-P-CeO2 NPs-4 nm) and unmodified polyhedron-shaped CeO2 NPs-10 nm (UM-P-CeO2 NPs-10 nm) can only achieve a yield of around 75% in 4 h due to their serious agglomeration. It is worth noting that UM-P-CeO2 NPs-4 nm and UM-P-CeO2 NPs-10 nm exhibit satisfying performances in the first 15 min, however, their catalytic activities decline significantly in the following reaction period. Such results indicate that the active sites of CeO2 NPs without SL modification can not keep efficient and sustainable during the whole reaction process. This completely proves the important role of SL in the cyanosilylation reaction. As shown in Fig. 3b, the reaction rate of P-CeO2 NPs-10 nm has an obvious increase with the addition amount of catalysts. The reaction was completed in 40 min for 5 mol% compared with 1.5 h for 1 mol%. Furthermore, the reaction rate was obviously enhanced with increasing reaction temperature from 25 to 60 °C, achieving a high yield of over 99% in a short time of 15 min (Fig. 3c). Fig. 4 compares the catalytic properties of the obtained P-CeO2 NPs-10 nm in the cyanosilylation reaction in different solvents and under solvent-free conditions. As shown in Fig. 4a, P-CeO2 NPs-10 nm can still keep high catalytic activity without solvents. The reaction is completed in 45 min. The avoidance of organic solvents meets the requirements of sustainable development. It can be seen that the reaction catalyzed by P-CeO2 NPs-10 nm can achieve a high yield of over 99% in 1 h in heptane, DMF, or acetonitrile as solvent, and over 80% in toluene and DCM (Fig. 4a and Fig. S5). This indicated that the obtained catalysts can adapt various solvents. Heptane is thus selected as reaction solvent due to its lower toxicity than DMF and acetonitrile. Moreover, the benzaldehyde with electron withdrawing (-Br, -NO2 and -CN) and donating (-Me and -OMe) functional groups can be converted into the corresponding products in a relative high yield, indicating the applicability of the obtained CeO2 for more aldehydes with different structures and even ketone (Table S1). Fig. 5 presents the catalysts recyclability, as well as FTIR spectra, XRD patterns and Ce 3d XPS spectra of the P-CeO2 NPs-10 nm before and after the reaction. As shown in Fig. 5a, the catalytic performance of the as-prepared P-CeO2 NPs-10 nm does not have an obvious decrease after 5 cycles. The reaction still keeps a high yield of over 98% in 1 h. As shown in Fig. 5b, the new peaks at 850, 1574 and 1670 cm−1 appear after the reaction, corresponding to the Si-CH3 rock of TMSCN or products, C-C and CO stretch peaks of benzaldehyde. The peaks at 1022 and 1070 cm−1 can be ascribed to silanol Si-O stretch, proving that the hydroxyl group or oxygen atom on CeO2 surface interacts with the silicon atom of TMSCN to form the Si-O bond [34]. Furthermore, the shape and particle size of CeO2 NPs do not have a change after the reaction (Fig. S6). As shown in Fig. 5c and d, P-CeO2 NPs-10 nm have the same XRD diffraction peaks and XPS spectra before and after reactions. This indicated that the crystalline structure and elemental composition of the catalysts are not affected during the reaction. It is worth noting that a complex process is usually needed for the regeneration of CeO2 catalysts for the following recycling experiments. Wang et al. employed aqueous H2O2 to treat the used CeO2, and then the catalysts experienced the process of being washed and filtered by deionized water, as well as activated at 400 °C for 30 min [34]. Garnes-Portolés et al. separated the catalysts by centrifugation and calcinated the used CeO2 at 400 °C for 4 h for the catalyst regeneration [19]. In this work, the used P-CeO2 NPs were only washed by ethanol once, and then dried in the oven at 60 °C for 30 min for the subsequent recycling experiments. Such a simple regeneration process will make the as-prepared CeO2 NPs have a great potential in the practical application. Table 1 compares the performances of our P-CeO2 NPs-10 nm with some reported catalysts and calculates the related turnover frequency (TOF) for the cyanosilylation reaction using the following equation: TOF = n product n catalyst × t where n product and n catalyst present the number of product and catalyst molecules, respectively, and t is the reaction time. It can be obviously found that the as-prepared P-CeO2 NPs-10 nm exhibit the leading position in the cyanosilylation reaction among the heterogeneous catalysts. Its TOF value is almost 8 times higher than that of other reported CeO2 nanoparticles, and even exceeds those of most metal-organic frameworks and coordination polymers. Only MIL-101 (Cr) with the usage of 0.3 mol% in the cyanosilylation reaction has a slightly higher TOF (80 h−1) than that of P-CeO2 NPs-10 nm (66.7 h−1). However, the reaction is completed in over 4 h and the 4th cycle reaction only achieves a yield of 85%. There are many factors affecting the catalytic activity of CeO2 NPs in the cyanosilylation reaction, such as Lewis and Brönsted acidic sites, oxygen defects and SL modification. Among them, Lewis and Brönsted acidic sites are usually seen to play the dominant role. Herein, pyridine-adsorption IR analysis was performed to test the quantification Lewis and Brönsted acidity of the obtained CeO2 NPs with different morphologies. As shown in Fig. 6a, the peaks at 1440 and 1597 cm−1 are attributed to the Lewis acidic sites, and the peak at 1540 cm−1 is assigned to the Brönsted acidic sites [42]. Furthermore, the peak at 1470 cm−1 is ascribed to coordinatively bonded pyridine or hydrogen-bonded pyridine. It is clear that P-CeO2 NPs-10 nm have the strongest acidity (88.3 μmol/g) (Fig. 6b). Moreover, P-CeO2 NPs-10 nm have the highest Brönsted/Lewis ratio, while P-CeO2 NPs-4 nm have the largest proportion of Lewis acidic sites. The overall acidity of CeO2 NPs is positively correlated with the performance of the catalyst in the reaction, demonstrating the dominant role of Lewis-Brönsted acidic sites on catalysts for promoting the cyanosilylation reaction. Fig. 7 presents the Ce 3d XPS spectra of the as-prepared CeO2 NPs with different morphologies, and the Ce3+ and Ce4+ components are labeled as u and v, respectively. Here, the peaks assigned v0, v1, v2, v0′, v1′ and v2′ are ascribed to Ce4+ oxidation, and u1, u0, u1′ as well as u0′ are signals of Ce3+ [43]. The overall areas of various Ce3+ and Ce4+ peaks are fitted and the content of surface oxygen vacancy is calculated by Ce3+ content, and the results are listed in Table 2. Clearly, P-CeO2 NPs-10 nm have more Ce3+ sites and richer oxygen defects, and such XPS results are consistent with TEM analysis. The formation of oxygen vacancies on (111) surface needs more energy compared with those on (200) and (220) surfaces [44]. Thus, P-CeO2 NPs-10 nm with (200) and (220) planes usually have a high content of oxygen defects. Furthermore, 3, 3 ´ , 5, 5 ´ -tetramethylbenzidine (TMB) was employed as an indicator to confirm the generation of radical oxygen species (ROS) during the reaction [45]. The solution color turned blue when the benzaldehyde was added. This indicated that oxygen vacancies on CeO2 surface also play an important role in the cyanosilylation reaction (Fig. S7). P-CeO2 NPs-4 nm have higher surface areas (124.6 m2/g) than P-CeO2 NPs-10 nm (98.3 m2/g), while the P-CeO2 NPs-4 nm do not exhibit the same excellent performance with P-CeO2 NPs-10 nm, demonstrating that the surface area does not mainly contribute to high catalytic activity in this system (Table 2). In addition, DFT calculations were also employed to determine the influence of SL on the reaction process and the chemisorption of TMSCN on the surface of CeO2. Based on the XPS analysis, we established the CeO2−x model with 10% oxygen vacancy on the surface layer, and added SL in this model to simulate the modified CeO2−x catalyst (SL-CeO2−x) ( Fig. 8 and Table S2). The carboxy group of SL dehydrates with the hydrogenated O atom on the surface of CeO2−x to form a stable modified structure. During the reaction, TMS and CN molecules are broken from TMSCN which are bonded to O and Ce atoms on CeO2−x surface, respectively. After that, TMS and CN attack the O and carbon atoms of carbonyl in benzaldehyde to achieve the product. Ce site acts as a bridge for CN transfer, while CN may continuously occupy the Ce site due to their strong adsorption and cause the deactivation of catalysts. The adsorption energy of CN on the SL modified CeO2−x is −4.49 eV, which is lower than that on unmodified CeO2−x (−4.84 eV). This demonstrates SL grafted on CeO2−x surface can not only suppress the adsorption of CN on the catalyst, but also reduce the CN transfer energy barrier, thereby accelerating the reaction process. Furthermore, SL does not affect the adsorption of TMSCN on the catalysts. The adsorption energy of TMSCN on SL-CeO2−x (−2.13 eV) is even higher than that (−1.98 eV) on unmodified CeO2−x. The adsorption energies of SL molecules and reactant molecules are negative, further confirming that SL has a strong chemisorption on the catalyst surface and the cyanosilylation reaction can smoothly proceed (Table S3). On the SL-CeO2−x model, the charge number of O1 increases from −1.22e to −1.27e due to the charge transfer from the C atom of SL (Table S3). Such charge transfer leads to the decline of Ce4 charge from +2.30e to +2.26e. This will affect the adsorption equilibrium of CN on Ce2, Ce4 and Ce5, and speed up the reaction kinetics. Furthermore, the position of CN has an obvious change that the C of CN tends to bond with Ce5 on unmodified CeO2−x but bond with Ce2 on SL-CeO2−x due to the charge transfer of Ce4 (Fig. 8 and Fig. S8). The improvement of adsorption energy and charge transfer are responsible for higher catalytic activity of the SL modified CeO2−x than unmodified CeO2 in the cyanosilylation reaction. Based on the above investigations, we propose a possible catalytic mechanism of the cyanosilylation reaction on the surface of the obtained SL-assisted CeO2 NPs. Lewis and Brönsted acidic sites of CeO2 show a dominant role in promoting the cyanosilylation reaction, and can electrophilically activate the carbonyl group of aldehydes. O atom on CeO2 surface as Lewis base sites interacts with the Si of TMSCN. Subsequently, TMS and CN molecules which are broken from TMSCN attack the O and carbon atom of carbonyl in benzaldehyde to achieve the α-[(trimethylsilyl)oxy]benzeneacetonitrile. P-CeO2 NPs-10 nm with diverse crystal planes are more likely to form highly active adsorption sites such as corners, edges and steps, which is helpful to speeding up the adsorption of reactant molecules. Furthermore, SL grafted on the CeO2 surface can inhibit HCN from deactivating the active sites on the catalysts, and CN has a lower transfer energy barrier on SL-CeO2−x model compared with that on UM-CeO2−x model, which is beneficial to more efficient reaction. 4 Conclusions In summary, CeO2 nanocrystals with tunable sizes and morphologies were successfully prepared by using SL as modifier, which were used as catalysts for the cyanosilylation reaction. The obtained P-CeO2 NPs-10 nm have strong Lewis and Brönsted acidic sites, exhibiting the high catalytic activity. The reaction can achieve an excellent yield of over 99% in 1 h in heptane, and 0.75 h under solvent-free conditions. The cyanosilylation reaction catalyzed by P-CeO2 NPs-10 nm still keeps a high yield of over 98% in 1 h in the 5th cycle, demonstrating an excellent recyclability. Furthermore, Brönsted-Lewis acidic synergy on catalysts is proved to play the dominant role in promoting the cyanosilylation reaction. DFT calculations reveal that the SL grafted on CeO2 NPs can suppress the adsorption of HCN and accelerate the cyanosilylation reaction. This work provides a new idea to synthesize efficient and recyclable catalysts employed in the practical applications. coredata.dc:description: Cyanosilylation of aromatic aldehydes has always been a promising reaction in the organic synthesis. Herein, we use sodium laurate (SL) as capping agent to synthesize CeO2 nanoparticles (NPs) with different morphologies and sizes, which are adopted as catalysts for the cyanosilylation reaction at room temperature. The obtained polyhedron-shaped CeO2 NPs with an average size of 10 nm are proved to have rich oxygen defects and abundant Lewis/Brönsted acidic sites, exhibiting excellent catalytic properties. The reaction can be rapidly completed in 1 h in heptane and 0.75 h under solvent-free conditions, achieving a high yield of over 99%. More importantly, the as-prepared catalysts possess outstanding recyclability that the reaction still keeps a high yield of over 98% in the 5th cycle. Density functional theory calculation is further employed to demonstrate SL grafted on CeO2 can greatly suppress the adsorption of hydrogen cyanide on the catalyst, thereby accelerating the reaction process.
coredata.dc:title: Sodium laurate-assisted CeO2 nanoparticles as highly efficient and recyclable catalysts for cyanosilylation reaction
